title: Sick of winter? Here’s what spring will look like in New England, per the Old Farmer’s Almanac
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Old Farmer's Almanac predicts warmer-than-average temperatures for New England this spring with drier conditions.
The forecast expects May temperatures in New England to be about 3 degrees Fahrenheit above normal.
Precipitation is predicted to fall below average in New England from April through May, with no significant snowfall.

title: Tony Dungy refuses to share if he voted for Belichick, Kraft on Hall-of-Fame ballot
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Tony Dungy, a Hall of Fame voter, declined to disclose if he voted for Bill Belichick and Robert Kraft.
Both Belichick and Kraft were not elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame's Class of 2026.
Dungy, a former Colts coach, stated he would not speculate on voting until official announcements are made.

title: ‘You changed my life’: Cory Durden’s Cinderella season continues with Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Cory Durden became a standout player on the New England Patriots' defensive line after starting the 2025 season on their practice squad.
Durden, previously waived by the Giants, logged 474 snaps and 30 tackles during the 2025 regular season, earning a 72.8 Pro Football Focus grade.
Head coach Mike Vrabel played a key role in Durden's revival, providing opportunities and support, leading to the Patriots' Super Bowl LX participation.

title: Payton Pritchard thrives in return to bench as Celtics roll over Mavericks: 6 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Payton Pritchard returned to the bench for the Celtics, scoring 26 points in a 110-100 win over the Mavericks.
Jaylen Brown had a standout game with 33 points and 11 rebounds, leading the Celtics to their 32nd win this season.
Cooper Flagg impressed with 36 points, 9 rebounds, and 6 assists for the Mavericks, preventing a Celtics blowout.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 4)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Abington home sales include a Cape Cod and multiple ranches, with prices ranging from $370,000 to $720,000.
Acton reported a one-family ranch sales price of $755,000 and a condo town house for $550,000.
High-end Boston condo sales featured a $9.5M unit on Dalton St and a $5M one on Devonshire St.

title: Manhole fires on Newbury Street prompt building and street evacuations
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Six manhole explosions on Newbury Street led to evacuations from Gloucester to Dartmouth Street on Feb. 3.
Boston Fire and Police Departments closed several streets, including Newbury and Dartmouth, to address the incident.
The explosions were attributed to an electrical issue; no injuries were reported, according to the fire department.

title: South Station’s new fare gates still out of service more than a week after snow storm
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: South Station fare gates remain closed over a week after Boston's January snowstorm delivered up to 23 inches of snow.
The MBTA shut down and wrapped the gates to protect them from snow, affecting operations shortly after installation.
Scheidt & Bachmann, which supplied the $1.3 million gates, is working with Keolis to restore service promptly.

title: Devin McCourty on ’25 Patriots: ‘A lot different than us’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Devin McCourty commends New England Patriots for their strong mentality ahead of Super Bowl LX under coach Mike Vrabel.
Despite past dynasties, the current Patriots team, led by MVP candidate Drake Maye, comes from a four-win season.
McCourty appreciates the team's different approach and suggests they enjoy their first Super Bowl experience more than past teams.

title: Woman who posed as student at Boston high schools accepts plea deal, sentenced to probation
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Shelby Hewitt, 34, posed as a student at three Boston high schools during the 2022-2023 academic year.
Hewitt pleaded guilty to charges including forgery and identity fraud, receiving four years probation and $9,000 restitution.
She is prohibited from BPS, future social work employment, and must continue mental health treatment as part of the plea deal.

title: BPS pauses new hiring amid deficit as district predicts hundreds of layoffs next year
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Public Schools face a $53 million deficit, leading to a partial hiring freeze on Central Office and school positions.
Three schools in Boston will close by 2027, potentially cutting up to 400 educational jobs, including teachers and paraprofessionals.
Rising costs in health insurance, transportation, and special education contribute to the district's financial challenges as enrollment declines.
